newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: DUTCH CENTRAL BANK SAYS GOLD VALUE PLANS UNCHANGED.
newsitem.headline: DUTCH CENTRAL BANK SAYS GOLD VALUE PLANS UNCHANGED.

text.p: The Dutch Central Bank said on Friday it was not planning an interim revaluation of its gold reserves in the wake of news Germany was looking to adjust the value of its reserves.
A spokesman said the Dutch Central Bank had 1,061 tonnes of gold currently in reserve, which it valued at some 11.702 billion guilders.
Bert Groothof said the bank revalued its gold reserves every three years and the next adjustment was due on December 31, 1998.

Groothof said the bank valued its reserves every three years, based on the lowest average market price for gold over the preceding three years minus 30 percent. He said the method could not be altered without a change in the bank's statutes.
The last revaluation was on December 31, 1995.
